conclusion: Analyzing the transition from state B to state C in the Stirling cycle to determine thermal motion intensity.
P-V diagram shows Stirling cycle with states A, B, C, D; processes A→B and C→D are isothermal.
Process B→C appears to be isochoric/isovolumetric cooling.
Thermal motion intensity is directly related to temperature; higher temperature means more intense motion.
Process B→C moves vertically downward; volume constant, pressure decreases.
For ideal gas, if volume is constant and pressure decreases, temperature must decrease.
Since temperature decreases during B→C, thermal motion intensity becomes less intense.
Second image highlights B→C transition in red, confirming pressure decrease at constant volume.
Final answer: Thermal motion does not become more intense during B→C; it becomes less intense due to temperature decrease.
